body:
same problemï¼š
nohup rclone serve webdav mypikpak: \
    --addr :8885 \
    --user xxxx \
    --pass 'xxx' \
    --vfs-cache-mode writes \
    --cache-dir /root/rclone_cache \
    --vfs-cache-max-size 10G \
    --vfs-cache-max-age 48h \
    --log-file /root/rclone.log \
    -vv &
 tail -f /root/rclone.log
ERROR :... Failed to copy: failed to upload: upload multipart failed... api error InvalidArgument: aws-chunked encoding is not supported with the specified x-amz-content-sha256 value.

The only changes in the pikpak backend itself from v1.69 to v1.70 was from 401cf81034f741793738e83d000a9efff568366d and they all look harmless to me.

We did update the AWS S3 SDK though which the pikpak backend does use.

```diff
-       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2 v1.32.6
-       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/config v1.28.6
-       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/credentials v1.17.47
-       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/feature/s3/manager v1.17.43
-       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/s3 v1.71.0
-       github.com/aws/smithy-go v1.22.1
+       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2 v1.36.3
+       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/config v1.29.14
+       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/credentials v1.17.67
+       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/feature/s3/manager v1.17.77
+       github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/s3 v1.80.0
+       github.com/aws/smithy-go v1.22.3
```

@wiserain - you have any ideas about this?
I will take a look at this soon.

Regarding the upload failure, this appears to be related to [Issue #3007](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/issues/3007) in the `aws-sdk-go-v2` repository.

Given this, we have a few potential paths forward to address the issue in our current setup:

1.  **Downgrade `aws-sdk-go-v2`:** This is likely the quickest solution as it would revert to a version where this specific integrity check behavior might not have been enforced or exhibited. However, we need to carefully assess the impact of a downgrade on other features and dependencies to ensure it doesn't introduce new regressions or break existing functionality.

2.  **Wait for an upstream patch:** The AWS SDK team is aware of the issue (as it's an open bug on their GitHub). We could wait for them to release a fix that allows for the proper disabling of integrity checks in multipart uploads.

3.  **Implement our own multipart uploader:** This would involve writing a custom multipart upload logic in Pipak, bypassing the `aws-sdk-go-v2/feature/s3/manager` package. While this gives us full control over the process and can immediately resolve the current problem, it's the most effort-intensive option and would require maintaining this custom implementation moving forward.

I lean towards exploring the first option (downgrading `aws-sdk-go-v2`) first due to its potential ease of implementation.

@ncw - How do you think?

@wiserain Well done for finding the issue. My experience is that AWS doesn't care very much about 3rd party S3 servers so fixing it will be a low priority for them.

If we pin the version, that will work for a while but security bugs in the library or it's many dependencies will force us to upgrade eventually.

What is the latest version we can use? We should probably do this for v1.70.2 but I don't think it is along term solution.

We have option 3 already in the S3 backend - could we use that directly?

This is the latest version I checked myself,

```
require (
	github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/feature/s3/manager v1.17.49
	github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/s3 v1.72.3
)
```

We can temporarily downgrade to this version for the v1.70.2, then I will investigate the feasibility of utilizing or adapting our existing S3 backend's multipart upload capabilities to replace the `aws-sdk-go-v2/feature/s3/manager`.

@wiserain 
> This is the latest version I checked myself,
> 
> ```
> require (
> 	github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/feature/s3/manager v1.17.49
> 	github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/s3 v1.72.3
> )
> ```

I double checked that and it seems to work fine. The next version of each package does not work so that is the latest we can have at the moment.

> We can temporarily downgrade to this version for the v1.70.2, then I will investigate the feasibility of utilizing or adapting our existing S3 backend's multipart upload capabilities to replace the `aws-sdk-go-v2/feature/s3/manager`.

I've added a fix to the v1.70-stable branch **only** with this in. This means it should be fixed for v1.70.x where x >= 2. We'll need to fix it properly before the v1.71 release though!

> I've added a fix to the v1.70-stable branch **only** with this in. This means it should be fixed for v1.70.x where x >= 2. We'll need to fix it properly before the v1.71 release though!

Thanks. Let me find a workaround before the next major release!

Thanks @wiserain - I ran the integration tests and they look much better :-) I'll release that in v1.70.2 today.

Can you also have a look at these remaining [failing integration tests](https://pub.rclone.org/integration-tests/2025-06-26-161137/index.html)? I don't think these are serious but it would be nice to clear them up or mark them as ignore in fstest/test_all/config.yaml

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e9e9b71c-dd9a-4069-8aa5-059fe0836081)

issue.title: pikpak: rewrite upload to bypass s3 manager

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the purpose of this change?

This pull request introduces a significant rewrite of the PikPak's upload, specifically targeting the direct handling of file uploads rather than relying on the generic S3 manager. The primary motivation for this rewrite is to address critical upload failures reported in #8629.

Key changes include:

* Added a new `multipart.go` file that implements multipart uploads using the AWS S3 SDK.
* Removed the dependency on the AWS S3 manager package and replaced it with custom multipart upload handling.
* Updated the PikPak test package to include tests for the new multipart upload functionality, including configurable chunk size and upload cutoff.
* Added new configuration options `upload_cutoff` to control when to switch to chunked uploads.
* Defined constraints for `chunk_size` and `upload_cutoff`, including minimum and maximum values, with validation logic.
* Adjusted default value for `upload_concurrency` from 5 to 4.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

N/A

#### Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-new-feature-or-bug-fix).
- [x] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [x] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body:
@ncw

I looked into why the `TestServerSideCopyOverSelf` integration test failed, and it turns out PikPak creates duplicate files with suffixes like `(1)` or `(2)` when we copy an object into a directory where a file with the same name already exists.

Because of this, our system retrieves the metadata of the existing object instead of the newly copied one, leading to corruption.

This brings up a question: Should the backend's `Copy()` function be called if the target file already exists? I've identified the root cause, but I'm unsure about the correct approach to fix this and what the right direction is for a solution.
